user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

This is an example of discharge summary letter:
Dear ___,

You came into hospital because you were getting more short of breath and your ankles were swollen.

A heart scan, called an echocardiogram, showed that your heart was not pumping as well as it should.

We started you on water tablets called Furosemide. They will stop fluid collecting in your legs and lungs.

Please take 2 Furosemide tablets (2 x 40 mg = 80 mg) each morning and weigh yourself each morning.

If your weight drops by more than 2 kg over the week, reduce the dose to 1 tablet per day.

We have asked your GP practice to see you in about 2 weeks' time. They will take a blood test to check your kidney function.

We will see you in 6 weeks' time in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.

You will receive an appointment letter in the post.

Sincerely,
____

Dear ___,

You were admitted to the hospital on February 10, 2024, due to symptoms including cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and fever. Upon examination and further diagnostic evaluations, you were diagnosed with lobar pneumonia of unspecified organism, indicated in the diagnostic code J18.1. A Chest X-Ray conducted on the same day revealed consolidation in the left lower lobe of your lung.

Upon admission, your vital signs showed a temperature of 38.5°C, heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure reading of 130/85 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92%. These findings were consistent with a clinical picture of pneumonia, and empirical antibiotic therapy with Amoxicillin IV at a dose of 500 mg every 8 hours was initiated. Paracetamol was administered as needed for fever management.

Throughout your stay, you demonstrated clinical improvement. By February 11, 2024, your temperature decreased to 37.8°C, heart rate to 85 bpm, and oxygen saturation increased to 94%. Laboratory results also showed favorable trends with CRP levels decreasing from 60 mg/L to 50 mg/L, and a white blood cell count declining from 12 x10^9/L to 11 x10^9/L. Further adjustments were made to your medication regimen, reducing the dose of Amoxicillin IV to 250 mg daily and introducing oral Atorvastatin 20 mg nightly.

On February 12, 2024, your condition continued to stabilize, with a temperature decrease to 37°C and oxygen saturation improvement to 96%. Plans were made to transition you to oral antibiotic therapy. By February 13, with your temperature normalizing to 36.5°C and further stabilization of your clinical indicators, including a CRP of 20 mg/L and a WBC count of 7 x10^9/L, you were deemed ready for discharge planning.

On February 14, 2024, you were medically fit for discharge. Your condition improved notably with the prescribed treatments, including the switch to Amoxicillin PO 250 mg daily. You are advised to continue this oral antibiotic for an additional 5 days as per the discharge plan. It is crucial to adhere to the medication schedule to ensure complete recovery.

A follow-up appointment has been scheduled in two weeks at the outpatient clinic to monitor your progress and address any further needs. Please reach out to your primary care provider if you experience any unexpected symptoms or if your condition does not improve.

We appreciate your cooperation during your hospital stay and wish you a swift and full recovery.

Sincerely,

___
